title: Meet Koji Tokumasu, the 'godfather' of Japanese rugby out to change the culture from 'robotic' to expressive
text:
A team of young rugby players from Meguro High School are huddled together post-match on a warm Saturday afternoon in Tokyo, while their coach imparts what Sir Alex Ferguson popularised as the “hairdryer treatment”. No matter that they were victorious; in conceding two late tries against Seikei High School, their 63-17 triumph is considered tarnished.

The scene is the perfect microcosm of school rugby in Japan: a gruelling environment which produced the bulk of those players who are one game from a World Cup quarter-final and it is hoped will push Japanese rugby to a point where such results become commonplace. It all begins with work – plenty of it.

For up to 300 days a year, every Meguro player...
